entry.title: Spring Boot - Sending Email
entry.content:
How would you send email using Spring Boot?

Often times, you would need to communicate with your users by sending them emails. This is very simple to do, if you just use spring-boot-starter-mail.

Dependency

build.gradle

dependencies {
	implementation 'org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-mail'
}

application.properties

spring.mail.host=${MAIL_HOST} # smtp.gmail.com # if you want to use gamil
spring.mail.port=${MAIL_PORT} # 587
spring.mail.username=${MAIL_USERNAME} # username@gmail.com # change username to your username
spring.mail.password=${MAIL_PASSWORD} # this is not the password you would usually use to login
spring.mail.default-encoding=UTF-8
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.auth=true
spring.mail.properties.mail.smtp.starttls.enable=true

Tip ‚ùóÔ∏è

These are the steps to get the mail password from gmail.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Click on Manage your Google Account

2Ô∏è‚É£ Click on Security from the left menu

3Ô∏è‚É£ Click on App passwords

4Ô∏è‚É£ Select Other (Custom name)

5Ô∏è‚É£ Name the app password and click GENERATE

6Ô∏è‚É£ Finally, you will get your app password

Usage

@Service
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class EmailService {

    private final JavaMailSender javaMailSender;

    @Async
    public void sendEmail(String receiver, String title, String content) throws MessagingException {
        try {
            MimeMessage mimeMessage = javaMailSender.createMimeMessage();
            MimeMessageHelper mimeMessageHelper = new MimeMessageHelper(mimeMessage, "utf-8");

            mimeMessageHelper.setTo(receiver);
            mimeMessageHelper.setSubject(title);
            mimeMessageHelper.setText(content, true);
            mimeMessageHelper.setFrom("example@gmail.com");

            javaMailSender.send(mimeMessage);
        } catch (MessagingException e) {
            throw new MessagingException(e.getMessage());
        }
    }
}

entry.title: AWS EC2 - Setting Up AWS EC2

link.title: AWS EC2 - Setting Up AWS EC2

entry.content:
What is AWS EC2

In order to have a backend application. You need to have a server. Not everyone has a server computer in their homeüòÖ. This is when you use AWS EC2. EC2 stands for Elastic Compute Cloud. You can borrow a server computer with a specific pricing that AWS provide. Basically, you can understand it as a rental server.

Step 0Ô∏è‚É£

First you need to have an AWS account. So sign up and get free tier for your practice.

Tip ‚ùó

If you are not prepared with your server application. Code First! Because you want to have your free tier as long as possible.

Step 1Ô∏è‚É£

Select the region from the top navigation bar. This region should be closest to your client‚Äôs region.

I am currently trying to have a service in South Korea. Therefore, I will be selecting Seoul(ap-northeast-2).

Step 2Ô∏è‚É£

Select launch instance from the EC2 Dashboard.

Step 3Ô∏è‚É£

Name your instance and choose the operating system you would like.

For my specific example, I will be choosing ubuntu 22.04 as it is eligible for free tier.

Step 4Ô∏è‚É£

Select the instance type that you would like. Depending on the computing power that you need, this may vary. Of course, if you choose a powerful instance, you would need to pay more for the usage.

For my specific example, I will be selecting t2.micro which has 1vCPU, 1GiB memory. This instance is eligible for free tier usage.

Step 5Ô∏è‚É£

Set up a key pair. This is not required, however it is important that you need to set this up for security reasons as you do not want anyone else to access your ec2 instance. Click on the ‚ÄúCreate new key pair‚Äù if you do not have a key pair already.

After clicking on the ‚ÄúCreate new key pair‚Äù, name your key pair and select the options that you need.

You should probably stick with RSA because ED25519 is not supported for Windows instance in case you are need Windows instance.

For private key file format, depending on your favor, whether it is OpenSSH or PuTTy, select the option.

Finally, click Create key pair and keep the file somewhere secure. If you lose this file, you will not be able to get into your ec2 instance ever again.

For the sake of my example, I am going to select RSA and .pem format.

Step 6Ô∏è‚É£

Next is setting up the network settings. If you have a constant IP address, and you will want to access the EC2 instance only from the specific computer, Click on the Anywhere 0.0.0.0/0 and customize it or select ‚ÄúMy IP‚Äù which would be your current IP address.

If you are having a backend application in the EC2, you need to allow HTTPs or HTTP or both traffic from the internet. This is your clients accessing your server for requests and responses.

For my example, I am going to run a Spring Boot application, so I am going to allow HTTP traffic only. Also, I am going to allow SSH traffic from Anywhere.

Step 7Ô∏è‚É£

Next step is setting up storage. For free tier, AWS allows you to have upto 30GB, but you probably would like to check on the pricing to reduce surprises that you might encounter in the future.

For my example, I am going to give 10GiB to my storage.

Step 8Ô∏è‚É£

If you want your instance to have GPU or other advanced setting, you can configure it in ‚ÄúAdvanced details‚Äù.

For my example, I do need any of the advanced settings for now, so I am just going to ignore this part.

Step 9Ô∏è‚É£

Last but not least, you need to select how many instance, meaning how many server computer that you are going run.

I am going to select just one for the sake of this example.

Finally, click on the ‚ÄúLaunch instance‚Äù, and AWS will prepare you for your EC2 instance. Congrats! üéâ

Step üîü

You have various ways to connect to your EC2 instance:

  • EC2 Instance Connect
  • Session Manager
  • SSH client
  • EC2 serial console

I usually use EC2 Instance Connect or SSH client as it is my favor of usage.

And of course, as it is default to be ‚ÄúOn Demand‚Äù, you can stop your server, or get rid of it any time you would like. However, you need to acknowledge that everytime you stop and re-run your instance, the EC2 IP address will change.

entry.title: Spring Boot - Validation Sequence
entry.content:
Why Validation Sequence is Necessary?

When working with DTOs, you are probably using a bunch of annotations to validate the data. However, what if you want to the validation to go in a specific order. For example if you use @NotBlank and @Size, you probably want to validate the @NotBlank before @Size. In this case you need to validate data in a specific sequence.

Dependency

dependencies {
    implementation 'org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-validation'
}

Usage

public class ValidateSequence {
    public interface NotBlank {}
    public interface Size {}
    public interface Pattern{}
}


@Getter
@NoArgsConstructor
@GroupSequence({UserSaveRequestDto.class, // Data will be validated in this order
                ValidationSequence.NotBlank.class,
                ValidationSequence.Size.class,
                ValidationSequence.Pattern.class
})
public class UserRequestDto {

    @NotBlank(groups = ValidationSequence.NotBlank.class)
    @Size(groups = ValidationSequence.Size.class)
    @Pattern(regexp = "^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$", groups = ValidationSequence.Pattern.class)
    private String username;
}

@Email in use

To validate email, you can use @Email.

Problem with @Email

The problem with @Email is that even "" is given as email, it does not detect any problem. Therefore, you probably would like to use @NotBlank with it.

@Email

public class User {
    @NotBlank(message = "Email is required.")
    @Email(message = "Email must be valid.")
    private String email;
}

entry.title: Spring Boot - @Size, @Length, and @Column(length=value)
entry.content:
Difference between @Size, @Length, and @Column

For some fields when getting a request from a client, there is a minimum or maximum length of the field. There are three annotations that developers use which are @Size, @Length, and @Column. Let‚Äôs find the difference between these three annotations.

@Size

  • JSR-330‚Äôs annotation
  • More portable than @Length because it is bean independent of JPA
public class User {
    @Size(min = 10, max = 25)
    private String password;
}

@Length

  • Hibernate‚Äôs annotation
public class User {
    @Length(min = 10, max = 25)
    private String password;
}

@Column

  • JPA‚Äôs annotation
  • Indication in the physical database column
public class User {
    @Column(length = 25)
    private String password;
}

entry.title: MongoDB - Versioning Schema
entry.content:
MongoDB vs MySQL

For my current project Gabojait, I am trying to use MongoDB. The reason why I chose MongoDB is to dael with various changes that can occur with the data in the db in the future. I thought the MongoDB which uses document rather than table, will be better than MySQL which uses tables.

How to Version Schema

The reason why we need to version schema is to deal with different forms of documents. For example let‚Äôs say that the previous schema looked like this:

Previous Schema

{
    _id: 1
    name: "Geomseong Ahn"
    gender: "M"
}

However, you need to add email when updating your database to a new schema to look like this:

New Schema

{
    _id: 1
    name: "Gemoseong Ahn"
    gender: "M"
    email: "gs97ahn@naver.com"
}

There are several ways to solve this issue when it comes down to database migration. One of the way, which I will be learned today is to add version number as shown below:

{
    _id: 1
    name: "Geomseong Ahn"
    gender: "M"
    schema_version: 1.0
}

By doing so, when querying a data, you can check the schema version and deal with the migration accordingly.

entry.title: Spring Boot - BaseTimeEntity for MongoDB
entry.content:
BaseTimeEntity setup for MongoDB is different

I currently am working on a project and I need to use MongoDB. I came to realize that I cannot use JPA anymore and need to setup BaseTimeEntity differently when using MongoDB.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Create BaseTimeEntity.java

@Getter
@MappedSuperclass
@EntityListeners(AuditingEntityCallback.class) // difference
public abstract class BaseTimeEntity {
    @CreatedDate
    @DateTimeFormat(pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss")
    private LocalDateTime createdDate;
    @LastModifiedDate
    @DateTimeFormat(pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss")
    private LocalDateTime modifiedDate;
}

2Ô∏è‚É£ Enable JPA Auditing in Application.java

@EnableMongoAuditing // difference
@SpringBootApplication
public class Application {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		SpringApplication.run(Application.class, args);
	}
}

The only difference as shown above are two annotations:

  • @EnableJpaAuditing ‚Äì> @EnableMongoAuditing
  • @EntityListeners(AuditingEntityListener.class) ‚Äì> @EntityListeners(AuditingEntityCallback.class)

entry.title: Spring Boot - build.gradle for Production
entry.content:
Code build.gradle for Dockerization and Production

The famous Byeong-Joon Song became a friend of mine recently, and apparently he uses this code for dockerization and production of Spring server. I looked at the code, and it is astonishing.

0Ô∏è‚É£ Setup

Well first, he changes the build.gradle and settings.gradle to Kotlin file

  • build.gradle ‚Äì> build.gradle.kts
  • settings.gradle ‚Äì> settings.gradle.kts

1Ô∏è‚É£ Versioning Server

Use Git Revision to use it for patch counting.

build.gradle.kts

plugins {
	id ("org.springframework.boot") version "2.7.1"
	id ("io.spring.dependency-management") version "1.0.11.RELEASE"
	id ("java")
}

val major = 0
val minor = 1
val patch = getRevisionCount()

group = "inu-appcenter"
version = "$major.$minor.$patch"
java.sourceCompatibility = JavaVersion.VERSION_11

/**
 * Get Git Revision Count to Utilize When Counting Versions
 */
fun getRevisionCount(): Int {
	val byteOut = ByteArrayOutputStream()
	project.exec {
		commandLine = "git rev-list --count HEAD".split(" ")
		standardOutput = byteOut
	}
	val output = String(byteOut.toByteArray())

	return Integer.parseInt(output.trim())
}

2Ô∏è‚É£ Docker Image Builder

Next step is to add this code for building docker image.

build.gradle.kts

/**
 * Build Docker Image
 */
val dockerUrl: String? by project
val dockerImageName: String? by project
val dockerUsername: String? by project
val dockerPassword: String? by project
val dockerTag: String? by project

tasks.bootBuildImage {
	imageName = "${dockerImageName ?: project.name}:${dockerTag ?: project.version}"

	print("[bootBuildImage] Image Name: $imageName")

	if (dockerUrl != null) {
		isPublish = true
		docker {
			publishRegistry {
				url = dockerUrl
				username = dockerUsername
				password = dockerPassword
			}
		}
	}
}

3Ô∏è‚É£ Refactor .gradle to .kts

Since the file is kotlin file now, you need to change the syntax of the code to come align with the kotlin syntax like the example below.

build.gradle.kts

configurations {
	compileOnly {
		extendsFrom(configurations.annotationProcessor.get())
	}
}

repositories {
	mavenCentral()
}

dependencies {
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-data-jdbc")
	implementation ("mysql:mysql-connector-java")
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-data-jpa")
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-jdbc")
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-validation")
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-web")
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-mail")
	implementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-security")
	implementation ("io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt:0.2")
	implementation ("io.springfox:springfox-boot-starter:3.0.0")
	implementation ("io.springfox:springfox-swagger2:2.9.2")
	implementation ("io.springfox:springfox-swagger-ui:2.9.2")
	compileOnly ("org.projectlombok:lombok")
	runtimeOnly ("com.h2database:h2")
	runtimeOnly ("mysql:mysql-connector-java")
	annotationProcessor ("org.projectlombok:lombok")
	testImplementation ("org.springframework.boot:spring-boot-starter-test")
	testImplementation ("org.springframework.security:spring-security-test")
}

tasks.withType<Test> {
	useJUnitPlatform()
}

settings.gradle.kts

rootProject.name = "cafeteria-spring"

Summary

I myself, have worked on a numerous projects and when it comes down to versioning, IT IS A HASSTLE. I would lose count every single time. However, Byeong-Joon does it simply by coding this to the build.gradle.kts. Now, I only need to worry about the major and the minor version number and forget about the patch number, as it is counting automatically. Thanks Byeong-Joon.üëç
